comment.author: 76381637@N08
comment._content: Unfortunately the best I can suggest is that it is early twentieth century.

comment.author: 23682239@N07
comment._content: McElhone Stairs are present, so it's after 1904.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Slightly earlier ..................................................... and much, much later.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23682239@N07] jrg_from_oz, the McElhone Stairs were built c.1870 - see NSW Heritage database: www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_04_2.cfm?itemid=2420979 The 1904 date may be when they were named after him (he died in 1898)?

comment.author: 23682239@N07
comment._content: We seem to have a conflict between NSW Heritage and the City of Sydney archives, with the latter stating at www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/aboutsydney/historyandarchive... that the stairs were built in 1904 and named in 1918 ..... There is also a reference in the SMH of 28 Nov 1953 (p9) to them having been built "some 50 years ago". However, most references seem to be c1870, so in the absence of any other definitive statement, I'll bow to the weight of numbers

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23682239@N07] That's interesting. I think more research is needed to clarify the construction date ... If we don't quite have a solid foundation for an "after" date, we may have a "before" (that is if we believe NSW Heritage! LOL). The absence of the Finger Wharf would appear to indicate before 1910, as the Finger Wharf was apparently constructed between 1910 and 1915: www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_04_2.cfm?itemid=5051359

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: It's possible the erection of the two nearby sets of stairs (Butler's Steps and McElhone Stairs) have over time been assumed to be contemporary with each other. Butler's Steps were certainly erected in 1870 (named on Wednesday 9 March) ... The Sydney Morning Herald, Thursday 10 March 1870, p. 5: They then proceeded to Victoria-street, Darlinghurst, in order to inspect a flight of steps which has just been completed there. These steps, which are very substantial and handsome, are built of Melbourne bluestone. They afford access to Victoria-street from the lower parts of Woolloomooloo, and will be a great convenience to the locality. Mr. (late Alderman) Butler was mainly instrumental in having them erected, and they were yesterday named after him, "Butler's Steps," - the Mayor performing the baptismal ceremony with as much solemnity as the state of the weather would permit. Of course, the Aldermen had to leave their cabs in order to witness the christening, and of course they had to enter upon another contest with the elements, and of course the elements, as before, had very much the best of it. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13201822 Empire, Thursday 10 March 1870, p. 2: They then proceeded to Victoria street, Woolloomooloo, where a handsome flight of stone steps, affording access to the lower part of the suburb, has been constructed. These will decidedly be of great benefit to residents in the upper part of the town, who will be saved a long round when proceeding to Sydney, or any locality about Woolloomooloo Bay. Indeed, the structure was generally pronounced to be "steps in the right direction." - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/60894721 I'm beginning to suspect the erection of the much grander McElhone Stairs were much later ...

comment.author: 23682239@N07
comment._content:
Returning to the original question, there is an article in the SMH of 1 March 1904 (p6) describing the opening of "New Bath at Woolloomooloo Bay". There is a very detailed description of the structure, and it seems to fit this pic, right down to being next to a boatshed ...

You're right re McElhone Stairs - further research needed!

comment.author: 23682239@N07
comment._content: The City of Sydney Archives has a map entitled "Atlas of the Suburbs of Sydney, ca 1885" online at photosau.com.au/CosMaps/scripts/home.asp. If you select the "City of Sydney" map, it shows the position of what would become McElhone Stairs as undeveloped. Butler's Stairs are present, but the position opposite the intersection of Rockwall Lane and Victoria St, where McElhone Stairs should be, is empty. So if the map is correctly dated, then it doesn't appear that the stairs existed in 1885.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: There are also no stairs in this 1884 map - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367478.html - In fact there is not yet even Challis Avenue. I'm willing to say you were right after all with 1904!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here's the 1904 SMH description of 'the new Government swimming bath for male bathers' - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14603313 ; I gather the larger baths built in 1908 were nearby - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14940527 www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/waterexhibition/BathsPools/Do...
